newsitem.title: JAPAN: US Treasuries edge down on profit-taking in Tokyo.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries edge down on profit-taking in Tokyo.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries edged down in post-holiday trade in Tokyo on Tuesday due to light profit-taking led by dealers.
"Prices were somewhat weaker after seeing the dollar falling off from its early highs, but the market lacked direction," a U.S. brokerage trader said.
Trading was nervous amid worries about the health of China"s paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, but the direct impact on the Treasury market had been limited so far, traders said.
The 6-5/8 percent 30-year bond stood at 101-4/32, yielding 6.54 percent, compared with 101-8/32 in New York on Friday.
described Deng"s condition as serious and said the government would closely watch developments.
"The dollar would probably react most sensitively to news on Deng. Given this mood, we cannot build up fresh positions in Asia," the trader said.
But underlying sentiment was starting to brighten following the recent convincing rallies.
Traders said the new benchmark 30-year bond yield may test below 6.5 percent soon, depending on consumer price index data due for release on Wednesday.
